Consider a system where the function \\( z = x^2 + y^2 \\) models the energy states in a two-dimensional space depending on positions x and y. We explore the effect of a rotational transformation defined by \\( R(\\theta) = \\begin{bmatrix} \\cos(\\theta) & -\\sin(\\theta) \\\\ \\sin(\\theta) & \\cos(\\theta) \\end{bmatrix} \\) applied to a vector \\( v = \\begin{bmatrix} x \\\\ y \\end{bmatrix} \\).

If \\( v \\) is transformed by \\( R(\\theta) \\) at \\( \\theta = \\pi/4 \\) and then the energy state \\( z \\) is calculated, will the energy state of the transformed vector be the same as if \\( v \\) was used directly to calculate \\( z \\) without transformation?
Explanation: The transformation \\( R(\\theta) \\) represents a rotation in the xy-plane, and since the energy function \\( z \\) depends only on the radius, not the angle (being purely a function of \\( x^2 + y^2 \\)), the calculated energy state remains unchanged by the rotation.
